>> It's my pleasure to
introduce Neil Daswani. Neil is the co-director and

the co-founder of the Stanford Advanced
Cybersecurity Program. He's an accomplished Technical
Visionary, Angel Investor,

Internet Security thought leader and he served in a variety of research development teaching
and executive roles in

organizations from Twitter and Google to Yodlee, and Bellcore. He was the Chief Information
Security Officer at

LifeLock and at Symantec's
Consumer Business Unit. He's also the co-author of the
book Security Foundations,

What Every Programmer Needs to
Know and next Monday he has a new book coming out called Big Breaches Cybersecurity
Lessons for Everyone.
My understanding it's already hit an Amazon bestseller list in the cybersecurity category.

As I always say, Neil is really uniquely positioned
as both someone who's been a practitioner
in the field for

a long time and really understands it from
that perspective, as well as an educator
and is really in

that unique position
able to give us a great overview of the
cybersecurity landscape.
With that, I'm going to hand the presentation over to Neil.

>> Thank you Pax very much
for that introduction. I'm thrilled to have
all of you here today.

Glad see hundreds of people in the audience
for this webinar. I'm going to be talking about

key takeaways from
recent cyberattacks. What I'll do is go
through a number of

different cyberattacks
from over the years up through the recent SolarWinds
hack this past December

and tell you about what might be something that
you can take away.

To just tell you a little bit about some of
the different breaches,

there's a whole bunch of
different larger organizations that have been hacked and
breached over the years.

I'm going to be commenting
on a number of them; Target, JPMorgan Chase, OPM up

through Capital One
and SolarWinds. I will spend more time ideally

on the more recent ones over
the past few years namely, the ones at Facebook,

Equifax, Marriott, Capital
One and SolarWinds. But I do think it's important to sample from some of
these mega breaches.

I also will be presenting data on not only some
of the mega breaches,

but on the 9,000 reported breaches that
have taken place to date. But we're not here to just talk

about the bad news and
what we can learn from it. I'm going to be spending
a little bit of time

talking about the Seven Habits of Highly Effective Security so
for those of you that are

familiar with
Stephen Covey's work on the Seven Habits of
Highly Effective People, my co-author for the
Big Breaches book,

Cybersecurity Lessons
for Everyone. We basically thought about
what are the seven habits that

are necessary to follow if you want your organization
to achieve security.

I'll sample from a
few of those habits, we'll of course to go into
much more detail in the book. Then I'll talk about

some technology defenses
that you can use to address the root causes of breach and I'll spend time talking
about their causes as well.

That will give you a
little bit of a sense for what we're going to
cover over the next say,

40, 45 minutes and then
I'm looking forward to taking some Q&As at the end so please get
your questions in.

Our team at the
Stanford Center for Professional
Development is coming through all the questions, identifying great themes amongst

the questions and
I'll do my best to address as many of those
in one shot as I can.

First, if we just look at some statistics from
over the years,

we can see that from the
period of 2005 to about 2009,

there were on average a few 100 reported breaches
every year and I

should mention that California
was the first state to pass a Data Breach
Notification Law back in 2003.

That's when data started
coming in even though there were also hacks and
breaches before then.

Because of the law, it gave more visibility into a number of these
hacks and breaches.

What we see from the
years from 2005 to 2009, is it was mostly organized
cyber criminals as

the Internet and the
Web started getting use for more and more
electronic commerce, cyber criminals realized that

there's ways to make money by duping folks and
stealing data and so we saw many of those
kinds of attacks.

Even in 2005, there
was a little bit of a concern and a growing concern

amongst government organizations that foreign nation-state
adversaries, we're getting into
the business of

hacking and breaching companies. What happened in 2009
was that there was

a suspected nation-state
sponsored attack

called Aurora that impacted Google as well as three
dozen other companies. Google was the first to
come out and talk about it.

But what we saw after 2009 was there was a
market increase in just the number of breaches that

we're getting reported per year. If we look at the stats
from 2010 up until 2018,
2019 we see that there was almost a doubling in the average number of

breaches that were
reported per year. Where we are now here in 2021,

we're coming off of the
December 2020 discovered

hack of SolarWinds in which
nine government agencies,

in addition to about a
100 private companies have been hacked.

Let me also mention that while that hack is referred to
as the SolarWinds hack,

SolarWinds was just one
of the companies hacked. There was approximately
30 percent

of victim organizations that
didn't even use SolarWinds. We'll chat more about that in detail in a few minutes here.

But that's some of
the stats just around a number of breaches that
are getting reported. Let me also mention that
the legal definition

of breach is when somebody's name and
sensitive identifiers

about them are inadvertently exposed or
stolen through a breach.

There could be all kinds of
system infiltrations where trade secrets and
intellectual property

and all kinds of other
things gets stolen, but may not necessarily
constitute a reportable breach.

That said, many organizations especially if they're
public organizations, they care about maintaining

trust with their
customers and consumers. They very often error on the side of reporting
security-related issues.

We'll see that in some cases there are some breaches
where for instance,

Yahoo when all 3 billion of
their accounts got breached, the security team at
Yahoo actually knew
about that back in 2013 or 2014, but it didn't get disclosed

until 2016 and there's more
fun to chat about there. While there has been

increases in the number of
breaches that have taken place on a per year basis, from the previous stats we see

that there was a
step-wise increase. If you hear any company say, "Oh, there's been an exponential

increase in the
number of breaches", that's simply not true. But what is true is that the number of records
that attackers are able

to steal in each breach has been increasing and has
not only been increasing, but it's been increasing
in a super-linear fashion.

That doesn't necessarily
mean exponential, that doesn't mean polynomial, but definitely increasing
in a super-linear way.

This graph here
shows the number of records that have been

getting stolen in a
number of these breaches. You see that going

prior to the SolarWinds
hack was clearly the largest breaches that

have taken place
in the history of the Internet in which
all 3 billion of their accounts got exposed.

>> Even though the

the question is how do you
measure the impact of that? Actually, just this past Friday, there were a number
of hearings taking
place at the highest levels of

leadership with the
Joint Committee for the Department of
Homeland Security

and what not that analyzed
all the breaches.

So how are all these
breaches happening? Why are they happening? What are the causes of all these breaches?

This graph here shows some of the causes as categorized by a database from privacyrights.org
of the 9000 breaches,

and while it may look
like hacking or malware is the largest cause of breach,
with the highest bar here, the second bar from the left,

there's some other causes that
I think are also notable. You see that there's a pretty
high bar for physical loss,

certainly over 1500 breaches and there's also
a pretty high bar for unintended disclosure,

which is the third bar from the right and there's over
1500 of those as well.

Why is physical
loss of say devices or unintended disclosure or
even portable devices when

portable devices
get lost or stolen, why are those breaches? Well, if you have data on media,

whether it be paper or
data on such devices, and the device gets
lost or stolen,
if there is unencrypted data, which has people's names

plus sensitive
identifiers about them, that basically results
in a reportable breach.

If you add up things
like physical losses plus portable devices plus
unintended disclosures,

the number of breaches due to those reasons is actually
larger than hacking or malware or organized
cyber criminals

or nation-state attacks. So what this means is that for
security of your organization,

one of the first things you
should do is just make sure that FileVault is
turned on on Macs, BitLocker is turned
on on Windows,

that you employ not only
storage level encryption, but application layer encryption

for all sensitive
data on your servers. So that when those
kinds of issues occur,

they don't just automatically result in reportable breaches. Encrypting data is
a very good thing.

Dan Boneh who's one of
my fellow co-directors,

he's one of the world's luminary authorities
in that area.

We have courses on how to use cryptography
correctly to encrypt things,

I encourage you to
check that out. Going on though, let me then now
focus on hacking and malware. I have this slide here which

shows unencrypted data as the most prevalent
cause of breaches. But there's a number
of other very

important causes as well. So phishing, malware, third
party compromiser abuse,

software security
vulnerabilities, and inadvertent employee errors make up the root causes of breach.

For those of you that are
in the field and you're working to comply with a whole bunch of
security standards,

whether it be PCI to
take credit cards, HIPAA to protect health
care information,

SOX if you're a public company, FedRep if you're doing
work with the government, there's tons of these security

compliance standards and they all have many hundreds of
checkboxes you have to check. But what I want to highlight in

this slide is that
while there are many, many such checkboxes, the countermeasures that you have in

place for these root causes, I would argue are
more important with regards to avoiding
getting breached,

as opposed to just showing you're good security hygiene
through compliance.

I think in some of the stories and histories of the
breaches I talked about, you'll see these root
causes at work and

I'll bring them to life
as much as I can here. These next two slides
have a table that

summarizes some of the biggest breaches
that have taken place. What I'll do is go into
details on some of them.

So I'm not going to
really spend much time here on the summary slides, but let me rather just get
into some of the stories here.

One of the first mega
breaches that took place was back in
2013 when Target,

the retail chain of
stores got breached. They had 40 plus million
credit card numbers
stolen and it was the first breach where CEO

and the Chief Information
Security Officer were fired. I think prior to 2013,

most companies thought about cybersecurity as an
information technology issue.

But in the aftermath
of the Target breach, it became clear that security and

cybersecurity is not just a information
technology affair.

When things go wrong, it's not just the Chief Information Security
Officer that gets fired,
the CEO can get fired too. In fact, with Target's case,

not only was the CEO fired, but the board was sued
and there were tons of lawsuits that the company faced.

The costs in the
breaches were upwards of 250 million and you

might be interested
in how did it happen? Well, the way the Target breach

happened is that they had a
third party by the name of Fazio Mechanical Services that were responsible
for the heating and

air conditioning of all of
the Target retail stores. Fazio Mechanical Services had
network credential stolen,
which the attacker used to then pivot into Target's network.
So third party compromise was one of the root causes here. Once the attackers got in,

they started sending
out a whole bunch of phishing and malware attacks. The attackers were able to
pivot from the network at

Fazio Mechanical Services
into the point of sale stations at all
the retail stores

because they had
relatively flat network. There was no segmentation
between different parts of the network and the more network

segmentation that
you have the better, so that if one part of
networks gets compromised, that doesn't mean
that attackers can as

easily shift into other
parts of the network. Now, Target had actually
bought $1.6 million of

FireEye sensors to detect malware and those sensors were
alarming, they were going off.

Their alerts were
getting processed by a team in India and those
alerts were getting escalated.

But there were so many of them, there was so much noise
that they couldn't get escalated and acted
upon fast enough.

Also the categorizations for the malware were pretty generic. So it's important to not
only have the defenses,

have the defenses
well tuned enough, so that ideally every alert is actionable and that you don't

have false positives
that simply generate enough noise so that you can
delve into the real issue.

That was the synopsis
of the Target breach. Major takeaway from that,

it made cybersecurity
a board level issue, cybersecurity is not
just an IT issue.
One final thing that I'll mention about the Target breach is

that it was the first of many third party compromises
that took place.

In security, we have the saying that you're only as strong as your weakest link and if the weakest link is
one of your suppliers,

if they are tied
into your network, if they have access to data, then they can very
easily be used to

compromise your organization too. The very next year,
JPMorgan Chase,

one of the top banks in
the country got breached. By the way, let me mention
that in the Target case,

what was stolen was
credit card numbers. So not the worst thing in
the world because you can

change credit card numbers
and it may incur some costs, but the effect of

credentials that
were stolen can be invalidated and you can
give people new ones. There are other breaches that

take place where
things are worse, the attackers get things
that are not easy to change. I'll talk about that
in just a second.

>> With regards to the
JPMorgan Chase Breach, what was stolen was 70 million plus customer
names and email addresses.

By the way for a bank, you'd imagine they
manage a lot of money. They manage trillions
of dollars of assets,

and in some cases
at least hundreds of billions of dollars of assets. It was at least good that no
money was stolen directly.

But what happened is when their customer list of 70 million names and email
addresses got stolen,

it opened up those customers to potential spear phishing attacks. When phishing attacks used to
take place on the Internet,

cyber criminals used
to send out tons of emails purporting
to be from a bank and hoping that some
of the recipients

would be customers of
the bank and would click on a link and go login
to an imposter site and then

the attackers could use
the stolen credentials to then try to steal money. In this case, when you've
got the entire list of,

say, JPMorgan Chase as customers, you can send out much more
targeted spear phishing emails because you know that they
are customers of the bank.
How did this breach occur? Well, it was a case where there was also a 3rd party involved.

In particular, there was
a company by the name of Cinco data systems that ran a
website that JPMorgan Chase

used to run and administer their charitable marathon
races on an annual basis.

Attackers had compromised
a website certificate for some code data systems and
were able to get access to

a whole bunch of passwords that JPMorgan Chase
employees were using to log in to that charitable
marathon race site.

Unfortunately, many of them
used the same password for that site as they did

for their corporate
banking systems. So attackers were
able to use that.

JPMorgan Chase was spending
over 250 million a year on

their security and had two-factor authentication
deployed almost anywhere.

Two-factor authentication
is, of course, that service which sends
you a six digit code to

your cell phone when you log in so that even if attackers
has stolen your password,
if they haven't also compromised your cell phone, they shouldn't be able to get in. JPMorgan Chase had

two-factor authentication
deployed almost everywhere. There was one server that did

not have two-factor
authentication deployed and so the attackers that were able

to take over that website
and get access to passwords were able to log in as

JPMorgan Chase employees without having to do the
two-factor authentication

because it just simply wasn't
enabled on one's server. So that's what happened
in that breach.

What I'm going to do is
I'm going to speed up. I'm going to talk about
the JPMorgan Chase.

I'm sorry, we talked about JPMorgan
Chase already so I'm going to talk about Office of Personnel
Management breach in 2015.

While the breaches
against Target and JPMorgan Chase were mostly

suspected to be cyber criminals, the Office of Personnel
Management breach was one in which it was

attributed to a Chinese
funded government attack,

in which the identity
information for over 20 million government
employees were stolen.

Most government agencies use the Office of
Personnel Management as their human resources
database, if you will,

and I think most agencies
except for maybe the CIA, were using this and

the attackers broke in to the Office of
Personnel Management. They were not using

two-factor authentication
very aggressively. They were under-investing
in their security program.

They were only spending
70 million a year, whereas even the Department of Agriculture was spending
over 70 million a year

and so it was a
case in which they failed to prioritize security
aggressively enough,

failed to invest in security, and failed to execute on cyber security initiatives like deploying two-factor authentication
aggressively enough,

there were a bunch of
very sensitive systems that's stored not only the identity
information but also

fingerprints for number of
these government employees. What happened in the breach,

is that attackers were able to exfiltrate that data
without being detected.

There were actually two sets of attacker groups and
when the OPM was

notified by the US Computer
Emergency Response Team that they were under attack.

They identified a
first set of attackers and took steps to kick them out.

But they were unaware
that there was a second potentially
affiliated attacker group that was in as well.

When you have a system where
you have attackers in there, you need to kick them all out at

the same time because
the second that the attackers catch wind
that you're onto them, they can then work to steal data.

They can stop their
operations around growing their footprint in an organization and they
can just steal data.

OPM attempted to kick
out that first set of attackers in what they
call the Big Bang.

But because they were
unaware that there was a second set of
attackers also in, they were unable to
stop them in time.

In the aftermath of all this, it was identified
that one in five of

the devices at OPM
were infected with malware and I talked

about the technical
route causes of breach earlier but three meta-level

causes a breach are if an organization
doesn't prioritize, invest in, and execute on

cyber security
initiatives correctly and aggressively enough then
you can still get breached.

That's the Office of
Personnel Management. It was probably one of the largest nation-state
oriented attacks.

The very next year though, it became apparent
that Yahoo had been

significantly compromised
by four Russian attackers, two ex FSB agents, in which,

what the attackers did
is they used malware and phishing attacks to get in to make their
initial compromise.

But one of the interesting
things that they did is that they, and one question is okay, even if they got in and
stole database of say

500 million usernames and passwords for a billion
usernames and passwords, the question is, how
did they get access to

all three billion Yahoo accounts? The way they did
that is they reverse engineered Yahoo's cookie
generation scheme.

As we know, when we
go to a website, we enter a username
and a password. Once you're authenticated, once your credentials
are checked,

then you are given a authentication cookie and your browser caches
that and really,

it's that authentication cookie that goes back and forth
between the browser and the server that authenticates
you so that you don't have

to type in your username
and password on every page. For those of you that
are familiar with

the HTTP protocol that's
used to run the web, it's a stateless protocol
and so the cookies are

used to manage consistent
state in web sessions. Basically, once the attackers
were able to reverse

engineer the cookie generation
algorithm for Yahoo, then they were able to login

to any Yahoo account at will, just knowing the email
address for the account.

Largest breach in history of
the Internet at the time. At the time that the breach

was getting revealed
to the market, Yahoo was in the process to
getting acquired by Verizon.

Verizon dropped their acquisition
price from 4.8 billion to 350 million less than

that in the aftermath
of the breach. Some of the root causes
we've seen before,

but what was unique is that they stole the cookie
generation algorithm. How your website
generates cookies is
an extreme critical importance, and I think it's important to reuse techniques and technology

that have just been vetted
and looked into over time. If you're interested in
the details of that,

we have a course on the foundations of

there's more about that.

Let's see, it's not only email

those email accounts
can very often be used to login to the banks

It is important to track

record related breach that took place at Equifax.

notified about by Apache,

but Equifax wasn't able
to patch that in time. But that was just the
very beginning of it.

In my book, I talk about how the initial compromise

within a few days of the vulnerability becoming
known to the world.

There were a bunch of requests
from Chinese IP addresses

that we're probing the
vulnerable Apache Struts server and seeing whether or not

The security team at Apache and the security at Equifax

many parts of the organization

But they had false
negatives in there scans, there were a bunch of
more detailed issues.
But once the attackers were able to leverage that vulnerability, actually a full two months later,

the server still
not being patched, they were able to start probing databases
in Equifax's network
because it was a relatively flat network and there were something like 40 or 60 databases that were

accessible from the

that were used.

>> Facebook has had a number of hacks and

it hides a bunch of
the menus and it hides information that I

But this particular

Facebook locked
down their APIs so that third party
developers could not abuse their service as easily.

bit about how that happened. Facebook has a very

Let me talk briefly about the three vulnerabilities

With the View As feature, there was a piece of
functionality which

allowed people to wish their
friends happy birthday, and there was a feature
that allowed one to

It incorrectly provided
the opportunity to post a video; that
was the first issue.

The second issue was
at a new version of that video uploader that

was incorrectly
provided access to, what it did is, it gave
more broad permissions

to the viewer than

that went wrong is that,

when it generated an access token to allow someone
to view the profile,

it didn't generate
an access token that would allow them to

the wrong token. It generated an access token for the user that

and that, if I
understand it correctly, also gave both, not only read access but also write
access to the profile.
There were tens of millions of Facebook profiles that were scraped due to this set

of three vulnerabilities
that came together. In many breaches, it's just one vulnerability

but this was pretty

the profile information
after Facebook had locked down a

There's been additional

also in 2018.

four years before

which is super interesting, I'll just mention that, we talked a little bit about

Third party compromises. The thing to keep in mind is that when you think
about third parties, don't think only about suppliers,

companies that you buy
software from, for instance. You have to think a little
bit more broadly than that. So when you're acquiring

or thinking about
acquiring a company, that company, that
you're thinking about acquiring is initially
a third party.

They need to be, not only
vetted like say a supplier, but need to be vetted in a
more rigorous fashion like
any potential supplier because after the acquisition closes,

that third party company, it becomes a first party company, it becomes part of
the first party. So if that third party is
breached and you acquire it,

you are breached too. What's really important,
even in public companies is,

while these things can be very sensitive when one company
is acquiring another, it's really important
to make sure that

the security team
has the heads up, and has the opportunity
to vet that acquisition,

not only by doing things
like penetration testing and reviewing the audit
and stuff like this,

but also doing pro-active
threat hunting. You want to make sure that they

have not been breached and just don't know that
they'd been breached. That's what happened here.

In 2019, what occurred was

the largest Cloud
security breaches today. Capital One is known
for aggressively

using the cloud and using Amazon Web
Services specifically. When you use Amazon Web Services,

they do a lot to protect

you are still responsible
for the security of your applications running

What happened in the case of the Capital One Breach in 2019, is there was a single
lone attacker.

It was not a nation state, it was not a cyber
criminal group, it was a single ex
Amazon employee who

technical knowledge about how the Cloud worked, but didn't even have

any insider knowledge
and was able to identify that

one of their EC2 instances, one of their virtual

Services platform

with a set of permissions on some S3 data buckets that

a 100 million credit
applications were stolen.

This is interesting

They were leveraged to get information
from numerous government agencies

the US Department of Treasury, the US Department of Commerce, Department of Homeland Security,

there were over 3,500 email accounts that attackers were
able to get a view into.

Attackers were also able to steal some attack
tools from FireEye.
